Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Story: This morning, as I was preparing for my meeting with Mrs. Evans—a parishioner who confided she’s been feeling lost lately—my dog, Max, started barking furiously in the hallway. I peered out to see Mr. Lee, my neighbor, wincing as he hurried past our door. I know the walls are thin, and Max’s barking has been a sore point for the building. As a neighbor, I feel the weight of their unspoken frustration, the expectation that I’ll keep the peace and respect our shared space. But as a priest, I’m also expected to be present and attentive, especially for someone like Mrs. Evans, who’s coming to me for comfort and guidance. The guilt gnaws at me—should I reschedule with Mrs. Evans to address the noise and apologize to Mr. Lee, or do I trust that my calling to help her must come first? My mind races, torn between the needs of my neighbor and the needs of my flock, both expecting something I’m not sure I can give at the same time.
